Award.AwardTitle: Cosmological Research with the 10-meter South Pole Telescope
Award.AbstractNarration: An overarching goal of this award is to continue astrophysical observations with the 10-meter South Pole Radio Telescope (SPT), as well as to support cutting-edge scientific discoveries and research analyses of telescope's data. The SPT research program for the next five years consists of three major parts: (1) the continued scientific analysis of, and public release of data products from, the recently completed 2500 sq. deg. Sunyaev-Zeldovich CMB survey; (2) three years of CMB observations with the recently deployed polarization sensitive camera, SPT-POL, including analysis and public release of data; and (3) the development and deployment of, and two years of observation with the new camera SPT-3G that, through a major upgrade to the SPT optics and a multi-chroic polarization-sensitive 15,234 detectors, will provide over an order of magnitude increase in the sky mapping speed. The data from each stage of this observation program will be used to improve tests of cosmological models and the framework of General Relativity, place increasingly precise constraints on the parameters describing the early Universe and the neutrino sector, map large-scale structure, characterize reionization, and provide catalogs of massive galaxy clusters, high-redshift lensed galaxies, and other sources. This range of science addresses some of the most compelling questions in cosmology and physics that have been the focus of several national reports. In particular, the 2010 Astronomy & Astrophysics Decadal Survey recommended the development of new instrumentation and observations to explore the CMB polarization. Through publications and data releases, the results of this ambitious program of technical development and scientific research will be shared with the community. The proposed activities contribute to the training of the next generation of scientists by integrating graduate and undergraduate education with technology development, astronomical observations, and scientific analyses. Research and education are also integrated by bringing research activities into the undergraduate classroom. The sharing of forefront research with non-scientists is extended beyond the university through a well-established educational network that reaches a wide audience at all levels of the educational continuum. Through museum partnerships and new media, the SPT outreach and educational efforts will reach large numbers of individuals while personalizing the experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported a major upgrade to the 10 meter diameter South Pole Telescope (SPT), as well as observations with the telescope and the scientific analysis of the resulting data.  The telescope design is optimized for low-noise, high-resolution imaging surveys of the sky at millimeter and submillimeter wavelengths. Using state-of-the-art superconducting detector technology, we use the SPT to produce very low noise images of the fossil light emitted a few hundred thousand years after the big bang, roughly 14 billion years ago,referred to as the cosmic microwave background (CMB).  The research we are pursuing with the SPT addresses some of the most basic and compelling questions in science: What is the Universe made of?  What is the fate of the Universe? What is dark energy? What is the neutrino mass scale?  Is General Relativity the correct description of our Universe? When did the first stars and structures form?  During the award period we built and installed the third-generation camera, SPT-3G. With its special built 16,000 superconducting detectors operating at only 0.25 K (-459F), SPT-3G provides an order of magnitude increase in sensitivity over the previous camera, SPTpol.

The combination of the high-angular resolution provided by the 10 meter diameter reflector and the exquisite sensitivity provided by the superconducting detectors, have enabled the SPT to make new discoveries in four main areas: 1) measurements of primary and secondary anisotropy of the CMB, which allows us characterize the initial seeds and growth of all the structure we see in the Universe today;  2) measurements of the gravitational lensing of the CMB, which allows us to map the mysterious dark matter that holds the structure together; 3) the discovery of the most massive objects that the Universe has produces, clusters of galaxies, from their epoch of formation to the present day by detecting the shadows the cast on the CMB, referred to as the thermal Sunyaev-Zel'dovich effect; and 4) the discovery of strongly lensed high-redshift star forming galaxies, which provide us with ability to study the early formation history of galaxies. The SPT program has resulted in over 150 refereed scientific and technical publications, which have so far generated over 10,000 citations. 

The SPT also participates in the Event Horizon Telescope very long baseline interferometry project, for which the SPT provides crucial long baselines and continuous 24/7 coverage of the region at the center of our galaxy. Data from the 2017 EHT VLBI observing campaign, in which SPT participated, was used to create the first event-horizon-scale image of a black hole, one of the most celebrated scientific results in recent years. 

The SPT team pursued an active education and outreach program. Collaboration members have participated in hundreds of public outreach events reaching hundreds of thousands of people, including new media and web-based outreach activities, including blogging, tweeting, Reddit, YouTube videos, and live webcasts from the South Pole. They created a traveling exhibit in collaboration with the School of the Art Institute of Chicago (SAIC), which reached broad audiences and was eventually converted to a permanent exhibit at the Adler Planetarium. In collaboration with Google, they have created panoramic, web-accessible images of the SPT and the South Pole Station, allowing people to search Google Maps for ?South Pole Telescope? and take a virtual tour of the SPT and surrounding environs. SPT team members have prioritized bringing the excitement of our science to traditionally underrepresented and under-reached groups, including tutoring and participating in residential science camps for inner-city minority students and participating in lifelong learning programs with economically and socially diverse audiences. SPT team members initiated a pilot program called First Discoveries to foster scientific reasoning through play and inquiry-based learning at the early-childhood level through a partnership with a local preschool.  

SPT students and postdocs have driven the instrumentation and analysis efforts. It is these university-trained students and postdocs who go on to lead developments at national laboratories and observatories (7 former SPT members, including four women, have transitioned into positions at National Laboratories). The breadth of these researchers? training and skills prepares them well for faculty positions. Many former SPT students or postdocs have gone on to faculty positions and a comparable number are using their training in innovative technical and computational projects in industry. SPT team members have also conducted a hands-on CMB instrumentation summer school for early graduate and post-baccalaureate students, to help prepare students for graduate work in CMB and related fields.
